--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:

> There's a =
new release (two actually) on sourceforge containing the
> changes. Like yo=
u say you probably don't need this now, but it might
be
> an idea to cast a=
n eye over the release logs as there are some
> changes/fixes you might be =
interested in. I've also migrated the
project
> files over to .Net 2.0.

Co=
ol. I'll go look over the next few days.

> I haven' included the zedgraph =
stuff yet, I'm still not sure about the
> performance and memory footprint.=
 BTW do you know if you can set the
> graphs to roll when the number of dat=
a points hits a certain number?
> This was one of the things I managed to d=
o in RudyGraph by using a
> circular buffer based plot set.

My model is su=
fficiently expensive that the impact is negligible. (BTW,
I've switched, as=
 recommended, from relaxing to a max 5 step evaluation,
which has doubled t=
hroughput). I don't know about "rolling" the graphs,
I suspect it might be =
achievable by deleting the earliest point(s) from
the PointPairList that dr=
ives the display.

> >You're almost certainly going to need to use derived =
data rather than
> >raw prices: percentage change from day to day is a good=
 start.
z-scores
> >are good but I'm always slightly concerned that they as=
sume that the
> >bounds of the range of source values is known. There are a=
 number of
> >other derived values that can be calculated from the technica=
l
analysis
> >(TA) domain, from the simple (moving averages, relative stren=
gth,
> >momentum) though trickier (volatility) to the downright exotic
> >(=
Bollinger bands, oscillators, fratal coefficients).
>
> I'll probably use p=
ercentage change pushed through a sigmoid curve -
> this means I can avoid =
normalising the range which will of course
> contain some extreme spikes wh=
ich would cause a problem for a linear
> mapping (normalisation) to the neu=
ron input signal range. I'm going to
> avoid anything too clever and let th=
e network's calculate averages and
> the like for themselves, at least at f=
irst.

I like the sigmoid "normalisation" idea. I'm going through a phase o=
f
seeking the simplest presentation that is consistent with making sense
at=
 the moment.

> Not sure about this. e.g. it's not like football where your=
 network's
> compete against each other and use memory (potentially) as a s=
ort of
> initial relative rating of two teams. Actually I was wondering if =
your
> pre-processing is actually providing your networks with information
=
> about the future, e.g. relative strength of a team determined from
> futu=
re results. Or have I misunderstood?

This may have been true in previous e=
fforts, but all I do now is run
through historical results for a few season=
s without making any
financial decisions in order to "calibrate" the model =
- it should have
formed an "opinion" by the time the bookmakers get involve=
d.  For each
run I now have it dumping all kinds of interesting information=
 every
time a new max fitness occurs. A number of interesting strategies ha=
ve
shown up, although I wouldn't say they look like they'll be particularly=

robust once a test set is presented...

Mike
